A TRIBUTE TO AMAZING STORIES
PROM CHINA
Editor, Amazing Stories:
This is my first letter to you, so I will start
in the conventional manner by congratulating
you on the standard of the mag. especially
the Discussions Column, the Editorials and
the stories by Dr. E. E. Smith, I like his
stories best because they seem to me to con-
tain more authentic science in them than most
others. Here is my solitary complaint; in your
May issue you published a story, "The Doubt";
though quite a good story, there was not one
iota of scientifiction in it. How would w»
feel when on going into a shop for a pair of
gloves we were offered socks, maybe good socks
but unsuitable for hands?
I was interested in R. W. Haysen's theory
of the conservation of heat energy by getting
in the shadow of an astral body. This hap-
pens to be in my line of study so I will en-
deavor to explain as best as I can where he is
wrong. His main fault lies in the concep-
tion of heat as being something material, "heat
particles or electrons" as he calls the trans-
mission of heat, being radiated or reflected
from the body.
It has been definitely established that heat
is another form of that omnipresent phe-
nomenon "Wave Motion" without which we
would lack heat, light, or sound. The nature
of heat, briefly, is this: heat or infra red rays
lie in that part of the spectrum between radio
and visible light rays; these waves are the
result of the compression and rarefaction of
the ether at such a frequency that they ac-
celerate the movement of atoms, thus causing
inoreased frictional energy or atomic vibrations
which reflect the waves, or part of them, the
rest being absorbed.
Now let us see what would probably happen
to our hypothetical "sky-pilot"; firstly, he is
in the shadow of a planet so that he cannot
receive any benefit from the sun's rays; sec-
ondly, the temperature of space is assumed
to be absolute zero, (--450 degrees centigrade I
think) and thirdly, the body has got to be kept
above a certain minimum temperature for its
proper functioning, such as blood circulation,
etc.
The only way our pilot could live would be
to bottle himself up with the vacuum flask
principle, for Nature abhors inequalities and
to think of this fellow trying to keep off freez-
ing by creating or preserving a body tempera-
ture of say 60 degrees F. with surroundings
at about "800 degrees below" is like thinking
of trying to drive the Leviathan at full speed
with a domestic coal fire. In fact, his body
may dissolve for 'tis said that at absolute zero
all atomic movement ceases so that our en-
terprising friend would find his body resolving
into chemical formulae. Not that I am try-
ing to ridicule R. W. H.'s theory or himself,
for it has often proved to be the tyro who
has shaken the authorities out of a recognized
rut of thought into the right direction. Any-
way, it has provided me with some thoughtful
exercise to marshal concrete evidence of where
he goes off the trail. And now, Haysen, is
your chance to get back at me, for the bee
has flown from my bonnet on that knotty prob-
lem, Gravity, in itself a grave subject.
As most of us know there are two forces
acting on us from Mother Earth, centrifugal
and centripetal force or gravity. Centrifugal
force is accounted for by the mechanical in-
ertia theory but not so gravity, this mys-
terious force not only counteracts the enor-
mous centrifugal force that must exist but also
retains a tremendous surplus of energy (sighs
from the world's budget balancers).
There seems to me to be only one possible
solution to this, and that is: it is nothing more
nor less than an extreme form of wave mo-
tion. For an analogy we can compare its fre-
quency with respect to the known waves to
ether's density with respect to ordinary mat-
ter. I do not mean to infer that ether has
an infinite density for that would be a futile
argument. To delineate, it must, be some form
of wave motion, for all bodies no matter how
small have a certain amount of inherent at-
traction for other bodies, as witness two small
pieces of cork in a bowl of water. Also other
planets and stars exert an attraction upon this
earth with ether as the only conducting medium.
So far as is known, ether can only transmit
energy by wave motion, therefore there can
only be one answer to this problem. I 'believe
magnetism also is kin to gravity but at a lower
frequency; we can shield bodies from magnetic
attraction, so why cannot we do the same as
regards gravity, once we get a better idea of
its nature, or when we find its frequency we
could possibly generate another frequency that
would break up the sequence. Comparatively
simple???? (once we have an exact knowledge
of its nature).
People investigating in that line, however,
had better be very careful about discovering
it for if they happened on it whilst standing
on the piece under treatment they would need
an army of scrapers to remove the effects of
centrifugal force off the ceiling. The pos-
sibility of conquering gravity certainly opens
up wonderful dreams. I think the fellow that
did that would be able to live on his royalties
(patents) quite well if he survived the dis-
covery.
Just one more piece before finishing: ether
does not possess infinite density, otherwise
the compression and rarefaction theory would
be washed out. If anyone would care to cor-
respond on above and associated subjects I
will be only too pleased to do so.
Sigmn F. Collins,
Royal Signals,
Whitefield Bks.,
Hong Kong.
(We seldom pass a letter from a distant
country without expressing our gratification
of having readers so many degrees of longitude
away from us. We carry out the idea ex-
pressed in your last sentence and we leave any
comments on your letter to correspondents.
You certainly have given a great deal of
thought to the subject of heat waves. We feel,
however, that speculating on what happens at
the absolute zero is decidedly unsafe as the
ether, after all, is still, we think, to be con-
sidered a hypothetical body, if it is a body
at all. The temperature of absolute zero is
--273.1® centigrade.--Editor.)

Editor, Amazing Stories:
I am writing this letter, not to tell you
whether I like your magazine or not (the fact
that I read it shows that I enjoy it) but to
ask some questions which have been puzzling
me.
1. The temperature of space is absolute zero.
Space is a perfect vacuum. Why and how can
anything freeze in space if there is nothing to
radiate heat to? It would seem to me that
an animal body, or any object generating heat,
would freeze itself.
2. It is a law of earth that "Nature abhors
a vacuum." It seems to me that it is a law
of gravitation rather than a law of the uni-
verse.
May I illustrate?
In many stories about interplanetary disas-
ters, the air rushes from the machine into the
vacuum of space. But it is also stated that
every celestial body, regardless of size, has a
gravitational field depending on mass or weight.
Why is it that a man who quits the inter-
planetary vessel may be drawn to the vessel
by its gravity but the air and gas leave it
entirely?
3. May I state my theory?
Gas holds the same relation to space as oil
holds to water. The gas does not mix with
space but emulsifies. It will collect in globules
around any body which exerts a gravitational
field. The ratio of density of the gas varies
directly with the ratio of gravitational attrac-
tion.
The heat of the sun on any celestial body
is generated by the bombardment of the mole-
cules of gas by the ions of radiant energy.
Therefore it is a physical impossibility for
gas to freeze.
The amount of heat generated varies directly
with the density of the gas and the distance
from the source of energy.
Please set me right on these facts.

AN APPRECIATION OF OUR STORIES

Editor, Amazing Stories:
Would you mind sending me proof that the
world is round? This may sound queer to
you, but I have recently heard an intelligent

pounded, as to the flatness of the earth. I, not
agreeing, but lacking the scientific knowledge
to produce facts to the contrary, am asking you
for information. I have been a constant reader
of Amazing Stories for the past three years,
and because I know of no other source to se-
cure the information I desire, I am asking you
to send me detailed facts to prove that the
earth is round.
Donald R. Scott,
1420 Lexington Avenue,
Indianapolis, Indiana.
(If you do not believe that the world is a
sphere, how can you account for day and
night unless you believe that the sun goes
around it and if you try to carry out that old
time Ptolemaic theory in the light of the dis-
coveries of modern astronomy, you will find
yourself getting into endless trouble. If the
world is not a sphere, how can one travel all
around it without tumbling over the edge into
space? The parallels of longitude (really
not parallels at all) represent the divisions of
time, fifteen degrees corresponding to an hour
of time, but these approach each other and
practically intersect at the North and South
Poles. If you could get close enough to the
Poles, you would find that an hour might be
represented by a variation in latitude of a
mile or less, whereas at the Equator something
like a thousand miles represents the variations
required for an hour's variation of time. If
you are in a boat on the sea or on the sea-
shore and a ship is approaching, you will see
the top of the mast long before you see the
hull because, as far as you are concerned the
ship is climbing a hill, as it were, to meet you.
This you can see readily on any clear stretch
of water running east and west for a few
miles.--Editor.)
A LETTER ABOUT ENTROPY WITH
ALLUSIONS TO A PRECEDING LETTER
FROM P. SCHUYLER MILLER
Editor, Amazing Stories:
In the April 1932 issue, you published a
letter about entropy by P. Schuyler Miller.
Mr. Miller states that the increase of entropy
is time. I wish to elaborate this.
Entropy is defined as the total quantity of
heat in the thermodynamic system divided by
the average temperature. By this is meant -the
unavailable heat energy. Let us take a body
which has a temperature of 20° C. and which
is constantly receiving heat by radiation. The
absolute temperature of space is --273° C.
The entire temperature between --273* and
20* is unavailable for any use. It is this heat
which is called entropy.
I assume that in any system, whose tem-
perature increases at a regular rate, the entropy
will also increase regularly. This regular in-
crease of entropy is time. Now, if the temper-
ature is increased suddenly, or at variable
rates, the entropy is also increased, but at vari-
able rates, and the flow of time is not regular.
Therefore, it may be possible to bridge a large
amount of time in a short while, if a way is
found to Increase the entropy of the system.
In the same issue, Mrs. Tuckerman writes
that an absolute Zero Is impossible in inter-
stellar space. This is false, and I wili attempt
to show why. Heat is the kinetic energy of
moving molecules. In interstellar space, mat-
ter is very rare, so rare that nearly a perfect
vacuum exists. Since heat Is produced by
molecular motion, the greater amount of mole-
cules in motion, the greater the heat content.

AN ANSWER TO MR. JULIAN GRAY'S
RECENT CRITICISM IN OUR DISCUS-
SIONS COLUMNS
Editor, Amazing Stories:
I should like to point out a few considera-
tions which, apparently, have been overlooked
by Mr. Julian Gray in his thoughtful and well-
written criticism of science fiction in the letter
columns of the June Amazing Stories.
To begin with, it seems to me that his defi-
nition of literature as being exclusively a study
of human reactions and character-development
is rather narrow and limited. Literature can
be, and does, many things; and one of its most
glorious prerogatives is the exercise of imagina-
tion on things that lie beyond human experience
--the adventuring of fantasy into the awful,
sublime and infinite cosmos outside the human
aquarium. In this genre, of which science
fiction is one branch, the main interest lies in
other elements than mere character-reaction and
development, such as would properly be empha-
sized in a tale of ordinary events and condi-
tions.
Of course, science-fiction can, has been, and
will be written with a dose attention to veri-
similitude in such matters. But for the initiate
in this type of fiction, and highly imaginative
and fantastic fiction in general, the real thrill
comes from the description of ultrahuman
events, forces and scenes, which properly dwarf
the terrene actors to comparative insignificance.
For many people--probably more than Mr.
Gray realizes--imaginative stories offer a wel-
come and salutary release from the somewhat
oppressive tyranny of the homocentric. and help
to correct the deeply introverted, ingrowing
values that are fostered by present-day "human-
ism" and realistic literature with its unhealthy
materialism and earth-bound trend. Science
fiction, at its best, is akin to sublime and
exalted poetry, in its evocation of tremendous,
non-anthropomorphic imageries. To demand in
such tales the intensive earthly observation of
a Hardy is idle and beside the point; and one
who approaches them from this angle will miss
the true value and beauty.
It seems to me, too, that Mr. Gray makes a
pretty sweeping statement in his remarks about
science fiction authors. Doubtless there are
hacks in this branch of writing, as in all others;
but, on the other hand, there are sincere
imaginative artists. One has only to name
A. Merritt (at least in his earlier work, such
as the original novelette version of "The Moon
Pool"), Stanton Coblentz, who has written
some gorgeous fantastic satires, John Taine, a
master of authentic science, and H. P. Love-
c.-aft. whose "The Color Out of Space" goes
Infinitely beyond anything of H. G. Wells in
its sheer imaginative scope and creation of
atmosphere. To say that science fiction writers
are "men of doubtful education and still more
doubtful intelligence'' because they prefer

cerely hope that such an improvement will in
time be brought' about.
There is one other matter that I should like
to touch upon: Mr. Gray's preliminary re-
marks about the general development of lit-
erature. To judge from these, one would think
that the world's literature is marked off in
perfectly distinct, geological strata I and that
all the former, more primitive layers are now
hermetically sealed beneath a deep and solid
stratum of realism. This, however, is not the
case. Romanticism, both in novels and short
magazine stories, is still the most popular and
widely read genre; and as for the supernatural,
which Mr. Gray puts at the archean bottom-
well, even that despised branch of literary en-
deavor is having its innings, both with writers
and readers. Apart from folk-lore, the lit-
erature of the supernatural is almost a modern
invention anyway; and some of the best work
in that genre is being done at the present time.
Realism, even though it is the only form
favored by the alleged "quality magazines" and
the self-appointed critical pontiffs, certainly
doesn't have the field all to itself. And I think
one can safely predict that it never will. The
intolerable conditions of modern life and mech-
anistic civilization, will, one thinks, be more
and more conducive to the development of a
literature of imaginative "escape."
There is still another angle which occurs to
me, apropos of Mr. Gray's letter. After all,
why shouldn't literature, or at least one literary
genre, emphasize what he calls the "inhuman,"
which, more properly, is tfre non-human or
extra-human? Isn't it only the damnable, pre-
posterous and pernicious egomania of the race,
which refuses to admit anything but man's own
feelings, desires, aims and actions as worthy of
consideration ?
This egomania, alas! is manifested in other
ways than through literature, and lies at the
bottom of that ruthless aggrandization, that
maltreatment of weaker life-forms, that pre-
sumptuous meddling with the delicate balance
of planetary forces, which may sweep our
present-day civilization into the limbo of the
dinosaurs. I fear that many super-scientific
tales, which depict a world-wide catastrophe
as the result of human meddling with nature,
may prove to be all too prophetic. Any type of
writing that would serve even in the smallest
degree as a brake on the madly careening
wheels of this racial egomania, is, it seems to
me, more than praiseworthy from a moral
standpoint if from none other.
Clark Ashton Smith,
Auburn, Calif.
P.S. On re-reading Mr. Gray's letter, I find
that I have forgotten to mention the matter of
H. G. Wells, which he brings up. Doubtless it
is the particular trend of Wells' mental develop-
ment that has led him, in latter years, to
abandon the writing of science fiction for that
of sociological novels. Wells, when he wrote
the marvelous "Time Machine," "The War
of the Worlds," and other fine fantasies, had
in him much of the artist, perhaps even a
little of the poet. These, however, have been
progressively smothered and drowned out by
the growth of the pedagogue, the utilitarian
"humanist."
As to Aldous Huxley, I have not read his
"Brave New World," which, I should judge
from reviews, is marked by the same congenital
pornography as Huxley's ordinary novels.
Satire, of course, is a well-recognized function
of much science fiction, and perhaps some of
it has been a little too subtle for Mr. Gray's
apprehension. He seems to have missed Stan-
ton Coblentz. of whom I have already spoken.
If I cared to. I could name others in whom
the satire is even more subtle and implicit.
If Mr. Gray should find my language some-
what violently polemical in places, he must
realize that I have merely availed myself of
that parliamentary privilege which he, in his
own letter, has already avowedly pre-empted.
In conclusion, lot me recommend to Mr.
Gray, and to others who are similarly minded,
the perusal of imaginative fiction for what it
really is rather than for what it isn't. Also,
he should realize that there are intelligent (and
not necessarily immature) people who have the
courage to dissent from the limited and grossly
materialistic definition of literature which he
has laid down, and who, moreover, are not over-
awed by the burden of present-day authority.
Auburn, Calif.
(The subject of science-fiction is more or
less abstract and cannot be treated like a prob-
lem of mathematics, but in science-fiction the
description of personality of the characters is
all important. Nothing can make a story so
vivid, of whatever type it may be, as a true
picture of human nature. However, we may
complain about its imperfections, we have to
consider human nature extremely interesting.
We have a very good gauge in our work for
our stories from the standpoint of this science-
fiction. We publish, as you have noticed, a
questionnaire. Answers to the questions con-
tained are to be found in the stories, and page
numbers are always given. Sometimes we fear
that we shall not get enough questions and
should like to have from twelve to twenty of
them, but somehow there always are a reason-
able number. We certainly agree with you in
your criticism of the special type of modern
fictional literature. Science-fiction does its part
to lift up stories and romances out of the rut
of realism, which, as you practically say, are
to be judged by ingrowing values. You will be
surprised if you knew how many books of
science-fiction have come out year by year.
One would suppose that no one would take it
up except such writers as H. G. Wells and wc
know that there is no living Jules Verne and
even Mr. Wells is flying off more or less on a
tangent in what he considers important subjects.
Then we had the Sherlock Holmes stories,
which of course have a touch of science in
them, but the author, Conan Doyle, was car-
ried away by psychic research as the subject
of his more recent years work has been called.
It does us good to read over your notes on
authors and comments. We have always felt
that our American writers, if anything, sur-
passed the English authors decidedly in this
line of fiction. Literature of the super-natural
goes back a good many years and it is called
folk-lore. We were certainly amused at your
comments on Mr. Wells' recent courses in
writing. We certainly agree with you.--•
Editor.)

As to the matter of slang, much can be
argued pro and con. I must say, however, that
Dr. Smith's characters are more true to life
than Mr. Campbell's. Whether or not this is
due to slang I cannot say, because I am sure
that Dr. Smith could develop his characters
without the use of any slang whatsoever. His
descriptions are far superior to Mr. Camp-
bell's, and I believe that I am right when I
say the same thing about his characters. Mr.
Campbell, however, has a better scientific base
for his stories. At least it is better in the
eyes of modern science. But I believe that
Dr. Smith has taken it into consideration that
over a period of years scientific views change
considerably, because he uses very few of the
modern scientific concepts in his stories.
Since an argument about scientific fiction
must necessarily employ quite a bit of beating
around the bush, I think that it would be a
good idea to use a few known facts--not
figures. I believe that I, too, could set up a
very great probability against the molecular
motion drive, but why argue about how many
angels can stand on the head of a pin? The
main thing is that two of the assumptions on
which Dr. Smith's story is based are now actual
scientific facts. In the Cavendish laboratory
at Cambridge University. Dr. Coekcroft and
E. T. S. Walton have shattered the atom with

there was a corresponding decrease in amperage
I do not know, because the details of the ex-
periment are secret; nevertheless, the fact re-
mains that atomic disintegration of the lighter
elements is an actual fact. It is also reported
from Ft Worth, Texas, that an inventor has
succeeded in imprinting upon fine steel wires
both sound and televisional impulses. A me-
chanical educator is not so highly improbable
either.

assumptions come to pass? What? Well then,
I am sure that Miss Robb's laurels belong
upon the lofty brow of Dr. Smith.

THE BEST AUTHORS IN AMAZING
STORIES ACCORDING TO THE JUDG-
MENT OF A READER OF MANY YEARS
STANDING
Editor, Amazing Stories:
I have read practically every issue of Amaz-
ing Stories except the first. Campbell and
Smith are undoubtedly your best authors. Dr.
Keller and some others run close to them.
In your reply to Mr. J. W. Buck's letter in
the April 1932 issue you said. "We are still
hoping to see the 'Skylark of Space' in book
form." Well, why not print it yourself? I
can guarantee you three sales in Pasadena.
Now the population of this town is about
76,000. Suppose you sold only three copies in
Pasadena, and only three copies to every 76.000
people in the United States. If that were true,
you would sell more than 4,500 copies on the
basis of 123,000,000 total population of the
United States. I think I have been ridiculously
conservative. Think it over, and in the mean-
time get Dr. Smith to write another "Skylark"
story with the same characters as the other two,
even a sequel to "Spacehounds of IPC" will be
very acceptable.
John Buddhue,
Castle Green,
Pasadena, Calif.
(We wish that Dr. Smith had more time at
his disposal so as to give us more stories. The
Teck Publications, Inc., has not yet gone into
book publishing, but it is not at all impossible
that it may in the future. The calculation of
the sale of books would be very tempting but
for one thing. As a boy said about some ani-
mal, "There ain't no such animal," as three
books sold for every 76.000 inhabitants. There
is nothing ridiculous in predicting a four or
five thousand copies sale of a book. Many have
been published with the greatest expectations
from authors and publishers but have fallen
flat. The public is a testy, uncertain proposi-
tion. We want to establish more definitely the
sale demand for the "Skylark" stories in book
form before we publish it, but we are more
hopeful of getting this started than ever. Any-
how, we would want a fair guaranteed amount
first.--Editor.)

PERUSED OUR MAGAZINE FOR OVER
FOUR YEARS AND DURING THAT
TIME HAS ONLY MANAGED TO REACH
THE AGE OF SIXTEEN
Editor, Amazing Stories:
Although only sixteen. I have been a con-
stant reader of Amazing Stories for over four
years. Through all this time I have never
screwed up my courage far enough to ask you
why you did not run a sequel to, in mine and
my friend's estimation, one of the best stories
you have ever printed, "The Metal Horde," by
John Campbell, Jr. This story appeared about
two years ago in one of your issues. (I believe
"The Metal Horde" is the name).
It dealt with the subject of brain machines
and interplanetary travel, and was a sequel to
"When the Atoms Failed". The story ended
very unsatisfactorily, leaving Earth and Mars
trying to communicate with the star Sirius. Let
the sequel tell of the success of the attempt
and the results of it. By the way, whatever
became of Campbell? He was good.
For the rest of the magazine I can say it is
okay and far above the other magazines of its
type on the market. There is one fault, how-
ever, that should be remedied. I agree with
the criticism of the Argentinian as the illus-
trations, with the exception of a few cases, do
not follow the description given by the author.
Vincent Doyle,
3280 Lynde St.
Oakland, Calif.
(As far as sequels are concerned, they rest
with the authors. We are sure that our favor-
ite authors, favorite in the sense that they are
favorites of our readers, would give sequels if
they saw their way clear to do so. But you
must remember that a sequel must have some
relation to the story and that a story which at
its end seems to beg for a sequel is defective
in that respect. We have to thank you for
what you have to say in your last paragraph.
The illustrations as a general rule, do follow
the description given by the author, as in*
terpreted by the artist. Interpretations also
vary. The caption for each Illustration you
will observe is taken from the text of the
story.--Editor.)
